Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
The long-term goal of this research is to identify and characterize the mechanisms for trafficking of plant vacuole-tonoplast membrane proteins. Chemical inhibitors of tonoplast protein trafficking and mutants with abnormal localization of a tonoplast protein were previously identified. The bioactive probes indicated that multiple pathways, including a novel Golgi-independent pathway, target vacuole-membrane proteins. This project will identify the mechanisms by which membrane proteins are targeted to the vacuole, and how these contribute to its biogenesis. The work plan will test the hypothesis that a Golgi-independent pathway engages in tonoplast protein trafficking, and will investigate a novel role for phosphoinositide lipids in plant vacuole biogenesis. The specific aims for this research are: 1) To identify the roles of IMPAIRED TONOPLAST TRAFFICKING4 (ITT4) and ITT6 genes in tonoplast-protein targeting by characterization of two mutants with defects in tonoplast protein localization. 2) To determine the role of phosphoinositide lipids in vacuole biogenesis. 3) To characterize the dynamics of the Golgi-independent pathway for tonoplast-protein targeting using real-time microscopy of live cells. Given the essential roles of vacuole membrane proteins in regulating cell turgor, and the storage potential of the vacuole, these results may have future impacts on the biology of environmental stress responses in plants and its applications to agriculture.

BROADER IMPACTS
Chemical and genetic screens employed in this project will benefit the field by generating novel chemicals and mutants that will be available to the scientific community. Some of the experiments in this project are amenable for high school and undergraduate research activities, and will promote the training of students in state-of-the-art techniques in molecular biology and fluorescent high resolution live-cell imaging. The PI will use these activities to continue to engage minority high school students from the NC School of Science and Mathematics with the goal of increasing the interest of minority students in pursuing science degrees within the University. The PI's laboratory will also host visits from River Oaks Middle School students to spark the interest of these students towards science-related fields, and to convey the impacts of scientific research to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The plant vacuole is an essential and dynamic organelle that is critical for the storage of a multitude of molecules including proteins of nutritional value for humans and defense molecules against pathogens. Changes in vacuole morphology are associated with important physiological adaptations that can affect crop yield. For example, the morphology of the vacuole changes dynamically during the opening and closing of stomata, which are the leaf pores that carry out gas exchange for photosynthesis. This research took advantage of mutants previously identified in the PI laboratory and resulted in characterization of regulators of vacuole biogenesis and remodeling:

1) REGULATOR OF BULB BIOGENESIS1 (RBB1). The vacuole membrane in many plant species constantly remodels with the formation of transvacuolar strands (TVS), which are thought to distribute molecules and organelles throughout the plant cell. We identified Arabidopsis REGULATOR OF BULB BIOGENESIS1 (RBB1), a large and plant-specific protein  that is important for remodeling of the vacuole with TVSs and vacuolar bulbs. RBB1 is a soluble protein but can associate with membranes, which led us to propose a putative role for RBB1 in membrane anchoring during vacuole remodeling.

2) The VTI11 SNARE and phosphoinositides. Another mutant led us to study the role of vacuole fusion and regulatory lipids in plant development and response to environmental stress. We determined that one mutant had fragmented vacuoles because of a mutation in VTI11, a gene encoding a SNARE protein. SNAREs belong to a conserved family of proteins that mediate membrane fusion in eukaryotes. Our results indicated that VTI11 function is critical for the establishment of the large central vacuole in plant cells as well as vacuole fusion events during stomatal opening. These results indicate that mechanisms of vacuole fusion that are controlled by the VTI11 SNARE and phosphoinositides are highly dynamic and are regulated by environmental cues. Given that stomata movements are critical for regulating CO2 uptake while minimizing water loss by transpiration, our results further support the critical role of plant vacuoles in plant physiology and yield. This work also revealed new putative targets for modulating plant adaptations to stressful environments.

3) The HOPS subunits VPS33 and VPS41. Homotypic membrane fusion at the vacuole is required during vacuole biogenesis, pollen germination and stomata opening. Vacuole membrane fusion in yeast is carried out by cooperative action of SNARE proteins, Rab GTPases, phosphoinositides and a tethering complex called HOPS (homotypic fusion and vacuolar protein sorting). The characterization of VTI11 and phosphoinositides in plant vacuole fusion led us to hypothesize that the plant HOPS complex interacted with SNAREs to mediate membrane fusion in plant cells. We focused on two subunits of HOPS, VPS33 and VPS41, as part of this work. We determined that VPS33 and VPS41 are soluble proteins that associate with membranes in part via phosphoinositide-binding. The two proteins accumulate in overlapping but distinct endomembrane compartments consistent with their roles in membrane fusion. In vivo and in vivo protein-protein studies showed that VPS33 and VPS41 interact with the SYP22 SNARE, which supports the hypothesis that HOPS and SNAREs work together to regulate vacuole fusion in plants.

Broader Impacts

This research supported the training of two graduate students and one postdoc. This grant supported summer research experiences (REU) for 6 undergraduate students (4 of them minorities) and one high school student (African American). The PI participated in the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences Disciplines, Degree Programs and Discoveries (CAALS 3-D) Summer Research Experience. The CAALS 3-D program brings minority High-School students entering the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics (NCSSM) for a three-day immersion in research. Students learned via hands-on activities about cell organization, the dynamics of plant cell organelles and plant responses to environmental stress. Six NCSSM students participated over two years. The PI also worked with the Booster Program at River Oaks Middle School, an alternative school for at-risk students. Students from 7th and 8th grade visited NCSU for half a day to observe plants under the stereoscope, and visualize the dynamics of plant organelles by confocal microscopy. They also interacted with graduate students and postdocs and saw examples of typical molecular biology experiments, including electrophoresis runs and PCR. A total of 60 students came to the lab over 4 visits. Perceptions of some students regarding science seemed to change positively, according to their written reflections after the visits.
